headline: Terrell Davis Talks CTE, Anthem Protests And Getting Stuck On A Deserted Island
short descr: The Hall of Famer covered the field in a chat with HuffPost.
image_caption(s): Terrell Davis gives Broncos fans a "Mile High salute" after being honored with his Hall of Fame induction before the Nov. 17 game in Denver.
article: DENVER â€• If Terrell Davis were stuck on a deserted island with an NFL quarterback and the two of them had to hatch an escape plan, heâ€™d want it to be Russell Wilson.But first heâ€™d need to know a little more about how he ended up stranded on a deserted island with an elite QB in the first place:â€œWhy would I be escaping a deserted island with a quarterback?â€ â€œWhatâ€™s my escape route? We flying off? We on a boat?â€In the end, the 2017 Pro Football Hall of Fame inductee, two-time Super Bowl champion, three-time Pro Bowler and historically great former Broncos running back said heâ€™d have to go with Wilson because â€œheâ€™s mobileâ€ and â€œthereâ€™s all sorts of situations heâ€™s able to get himself out of.â€Davis, 45, talked about that, player safety, anthem protests and more in an interview with HuffPost on Thursday morning. Davis was speaking to reporters as part of a promotional push for Verizonâ€™s new rewards program, VerizonUp. (Note: Verizon owns HuffPostâ€™s parent company, Oath.) The interview has been lightly edited for clarity and transcribed below:HuffPost: Letâ€™s say tomorrow you wake up, and youâ€™ve been named NFL commissioner, with the absolute power to change anything in the league. Whatâ€™s the first thing youâ€™d do? Davis: I would go back to giving teams more time to practice. More time for padded practices, more time to develop players. Theyâ€™ve really taken it away from the players â€• and a lot of that has been done by the NFL Players Association â€• but itâ€™s kind of cheating the players in their development.Training camp is important. The way weâ€™re preparing players coming out of college. Especially the offensive linemen and running backs, in trying to get the running game going, you need actual practice in pads. Itâ€™s hard to really get that running game going when youâ€™re just doing simulated drills or youâ€™re doing walk-throughs. I know what it meant to me to get those reps in, and Iâ€™m sure it would benefit a lot of other players.Whatâ€™s stopping NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell or the NFLPA from doing that?It all comes back to playersâ€™ safety, and I think the one thing that hurts it is you have some coaches who abuse it, and thatâ€™s why they installed it initially. You had some coaches who were practicing super long â€• two practices a day with pads on. Iâ€™m not sure how you could bring that back and try to make sure that itâ€™s not being abused and that itâ€™s being used properly. If you could time travel, what advice would you give yourself before your first preseason game in 1995, when you were pretty sure you wouldnâ€™t make the team?Just be ready for the opportunity. When it comes, itâ€™s going to come. I canâ€™t tell you when, but when it comes â€• be ready.I know you fought through migraines in the past. Are you worried about chronic traumatic encephelopathy at all and how CTE might affect you in the future?Yeah, I think you certainly have to be. This sport is relatively new, and weâ€™re just now starting to see players getting older, getting their brains examined and having signs of CTE, so why would I think that Iâ€™m in the clear?There are things that have happened in my life where I might forget something, and, of course, my first thought is, â€œIs this from playing football or am I getting older?â€ And Iâ€™m not sure. I have a wife and three kids, and youâ€™re always concerned about your health. Are you going to be around when they get older? Yeah, I think about it.I do know that [when I played] 18 years ago, I thought I wouldnâ€™t let my kids play football. Iâ€™ve changed my tune for a number of reasons: One, the sport has changed and the awareness is there. If you get dinged and you see stars, you now have to go through the proper protocol, so I like what theyâ€™re doing with that. Going back to the grassroots, people growing up playing football are taught differently. The equipment is better. Techniques are being taught differently in terms of where your head should be placed. They donâ€™t hit as much on all levels. Everything theyâ€™ve done to decrease the chances of head collisions Iâ€™ve been happy with. Both of my sons play flag football, and they want to play tackle. And when itâ€™s time to play tackle, Iâ€™m going to let them play.What would you tell NFL players who are concerned about CTE and are looking at their future, thinking of leaving the league early?The first thing to do is look at what their history is. If they have a history of concussions, then I canâ€™t tell anybody to continue to play. Itâ€™s really an individual decision. If you donâ€™t have a history of it and you havenâ€™t had any concussions or signs of head trauma, I would tell them the game is safe. And itâ€™s getting safer every day. I donâ€™t tell players whether they should play or not, itâ€™s just up to them.If you were stuck on a deserted island with a QB whoâ€™s currently in the league and you had to escape, who would it be, and why?[Laughing] Why would I be escaping a deserted island with a quarterback? Depends on how weâ€™re getting off the island. Whatâ€™s my escape route? We flying off? We on a boat?Give me Russell Wilson, man. Iâ€™m a Russell fan. Heâ€™s got all the attacks. Heâ€™s mobile, heâ€™s able to deal, thereâ€™s all sorts of situations heâ€™s able to get himself out of. Heâ€™s a one-man showdown up there in Seattle. I like Russell.You came up with your famous touchdown celebration, the Mile High salute, as a sign of respect for servicemen and women. Is there any advice youâ€™d give players who are kneeling during the anthem in protest of racial inequality?No. Those players werenâ€™t kneeling because they donâ€™t like the military. I stand. I also understand people who donâ€™t want to stand for the anthem and why theyâ€™re doing it: Itâ€™s not about our military, itâ€™s not about them not liking America. Theyâ€™re just bringing attention to an issue in the communities that they come from. And Iâ€™m all for that.This is a country where weâ€™re taught to fight for things we believe in and speak for people who donâ€™t have a voice. Iâ€™ve spoken to a number of servicemen and women who have shared that they donâ€™t mind â€• that thatâ€™s what they fought for, for us to have that platform and to have the right to do that. So long as itâ€™s a peaceful assembly in protest, they were all for that.

headline: Get Ready For A Biopic About Hattie McDaniel, The First Black Oscar Winner
short descr: She won an Academy Award for her role in 1939's "Gone With The Wind."
image_caption(s): McDaniel in the 1939 film "Gone With The Wind," alongside British actress Vivien Leigh.
article: Hattie McDaniel, the first black person to win an Oscar, is reportedly the subject of a forthcoming biopic.Producers Aaron Magnani and Alysia Allen have obtained the rights to Hattie McDaniel: Black Ambition, White Hollywood, a biography Jill Watts published in 2007, Variety reported earlier this week. McDaniel won the Oscar for Best Supporting Actress in 1940 for her role as the house servant â€œMammyâ€ in â€œGone With The Wind.â€ It wasnâ€™t until 1964 that the next black actor, Sidney Poitier, would win an Academy Award. â€œGone With The Windâ€ won eight Oscars, but all of its black actors â€• including McDaniel â€• were prohibited from attending the movieâ€™s premiere in Georgia. McDaniel, a native of Wichita, Kansas, was born in 1893 to parents who were freed slaves. She started her career in entertainment as a vaudeville performer, which was a community of entertainers that appeared in variety shows around the U.S. in the late 19th century. She appeared on a radio show in the 1920s, making her one of the first black women to do so, and made her film debut in â€œThe Golden Westâ€ in 1932. Civil rights groups criticized the actress for commonly taking on roles portraying domestic workers such as cooks and maids, and the NAACP said her characters often embodied negative racial stereotypes. â€œI have never apologized for the roles I play,â€ she wrote in a 1947 article later published in The Hollywood Reporter.She added that she was happy about winning her Oscar, writing:â€œMy own people were especially happy. They felt that in honoring me, Hollywood had honored the entire race. That was the way I wanted it. This was too big a moment for my personal back-slapping. I wanted this occasion to prove an inspiration to Negro youth for many years to come.â€ CORRECTION: A previous version of this article incorrectly stated that McDaniel won her Oscar in 1939. â€œGone With The Windâ€ was released in 1939, but the award ceremony was held in 1940.

headline: Singer Seal Accuses Oprah Of Knowing About Weinstein Rumors 'For Decades'
short descr: He claimed the media mogul is â€œpart of the problem,â€ not the solution.

article: Musician Seal isnâ€™t buying that Oprah Winfrey is a champion of women.Days after the media mogulâ€™s powerful speech at the Golden Globes proclaimed â€œtime is upâ€ for men in power who silence women, Seal published a fiery post on Instagram Wednesday that included two photos of Winfrey with the disgraced producer Harvey Weinstein, whose alleged serial sex crimes sparked the #MeToo movement and a cascade of accusations of abuse, harassment and assault against powerful men.Superimposed on the photos in Sealâ€™s post are the words: â€œWhen you have been part of the problem for decades but suddenly they all think you are the solution.â€His caption alleges Winfrey knew about Weinsteinâ€™s sexual misconduct. â€œOh I forgot, thatâ€™s right.....youâ€™d heard the rumours but you had no idea he was actually serially assaulting young stary-eyed [sic] actresses who in turn had no idea what they were getting into. The stirring address prompted speculation she might run for president in 2020.â€œThe Daily Showâ€ host Trevor Noah said Winfrey would be the â€œperfect opponentâ€ for President Donald Trump because â€œsheâ€™s everything that heâ€™s not.â€Others are skeptical of another celebrity running for the presidency. â€œOprah is beyond doubt a magnificent orator,â€ â€œFamily Guyâ€ creator Seth MacFarlane tweeted on Tuesday. â€œBut the idea of a reality show star running against a talk show host is troublingly dystopian. headline: Government Shutdown Nears But Congress, White House â€˜A Long Waysâ€™ From DACA Deal
short descr: A bipartisan group of senators came to an agreement. But the White House and other senators haven't said yes yet.
image_caption(s): Secretary of Homeland Security Kirstjen Nielsen, center, and Rep. Bob Goodlatte (R-Va.), second left, smile during a meeting with President Donald Trump and bipartisan members of Congress on immigration on Tuesday.
article: WASHINGTON â€• For a fleeting moment on Thursday, it sounded like there might have been a major breakthrough in Congress to protect Dreamers, the young undocumented immigrants who came to the United States as children. Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), one of six senators working on a Dreamer bill, told reporters that the group had agreed on a package that would renew the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) immigration program. But not long after the initial news, the White House and other Republicans rushed to deny any deal had been reached. Negotiations still have â€œa long ways to go,â€ White House legislative affairs director Marc Short said Thursday afternoon. With only eight days until a government shutdown, lawmakers still havenâ€™t come to an agreement even within their own parties on what to do about DACA. Democrats want a legislative solution for Dreamers to be part of any must-pass spending package, and many have said they wonâ€™t accept certain trade-offs. Meanwhile, many Republicans are just as strong-headed that they wonâ€™t budge without new immigration restrictions.At a White House meeting on Thursday, President Donald Trump told a bipartisan group of lawmakers to keep working and rejected the proposal from the group of six that Flake is a part of, according to Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.), who was in the meeting and represents the more restrictionist flank of the party on immigration.â€œItâ€™s not even a fig leaf. Itâ€™s a pine needle,â€ Cotton told reporters. He added later, â€œItâ€™s a joke of a proposal.â€During Thursdayâ€™s meeting with lawmakers, Trump reportedly slammed the idea of restoring protections for immigrants from â€œshitholeâ€ countriesEarlier this week, Trump told lawmakers at the White House that he wants three concessions in exchange for signing protections for Dreamers. First, he wants border security, including his signature wall. Second, he wants an end to the diversity visa lottery, which grants green cards to up to 50,000 people from countries with low immigration levels, after vetting. And finally, Trump wants to end what he calls â€œchain migration,â€ a term for allowing Americans and legal permanent residents to sponsor family for green cards beyond spouses and minor children.The White House hasnâ€™t yet said what it would be willing to agree to for actually helping Dreamers. Short told reporters that it would be narrower than the Dream Act â€• a bill to grant legal status to a larger group of young undocumented immigrants than DACA â€• but that Trump was open to eventual legal status and citizenship, depending on what he got in return. The six-senator groupâ€™s deal addresses all of the areas the president asked for, according to a statement released on Thursday afternoon by the group, which along with Flake includes Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.). Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), Michael Bennet (D-Colo.), Cory Gardner (R-Colo.), and Bob Menendez (D-N.J.). They have not yet released the proposal publicly but said they â€œare now working to build support for that deal in Congress.â€But the proposal put forward by the group of six in the Senate remains far from what House Republicans are proposing. Lawmakers there have taken Trumpâ€™s principles and put forward a bill with even more immigration restrictions, though they say their additional measures are all part of the â€œborder securityâ€ plank. The White House issued a statement praising the bill but singling out only its previously-stated policy principles.Democrats immediately dismissed that House GOP bill, with progressive coalitions in Congress pushing back against Trumpâ€™s initial demands, let alone the expanded provisions in the Republican legislation.The Congressional Tri-Caucus â€• made up of the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus, the Congressional Black Caucus and the Congressional Hispanic Caucus â€• has called for a â€œcleanâ€ bill to help Dreamers. If they donâ€™t get help for Dreamers, theyâ€™re not going to vote for a funding bill, said Hispanic Caucus member Ruben Gallego (D-Ariz.).Democratic members have suggested theyâ€™re willing to negotiate on some issues, but there are lines they wonâ€™t cross. Eliminating the diversity visa lottery and family-based visas isnâ€™t something Democrats could support, Rep. RaÃºl Grijalva (D-Ariz.) said, although he added that they might discuss changes to how to administer or lay out the programs. Some lawmakers have floated ending the diversity visa lottery but giving those visas to people who hold temporary protected status. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee (D-Texas), a member of the Congressional Black Caucus, said that would amount to pitting â€œneedy people against needy people.â€ â€œThat is taking the last crumbs out of the basket, walking into an impoverished community and throwing them on the ground,â€ Jackson Lee said. â€œThat is unacceptable.â€ Rep. Norma Torres (D-Calif.), another member of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, said if a deal includes ending the diversity visa lottery and ending family-based visa categories, sheâ€™d likely oppose it.â€œWe should not be talking about anything other than fixing [Dreamersâ€™] immigration status,â€ she said. If thatâ€™s the standard for Democrats on the left, and if Republicans in Congress and the White House are still insisting on items like a wall and an end, in their words, to â€œchain migration,â€ itâ€™s difficult to see any quick agreement.If no deal comes together over the next week, Congress must pass yet another short-term funding extension, their fourth for a fiscal year that began in October. House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) said Thursday he planned to put forth another â€œcleanâ€ continuing resolution (CR) next week, with a broader deal already looking unlikely to be finalized in a few legislative days.But Democrats arenâ€™t sounding all that supportive of another short-term extension, with progressives in the House signaling that delaying this fight even longer isnâ€™t palatable to them. At the end of December, 119 Democrats voted against a CR, and that number could quickly rise next week. Complicating this legislative discussion is the fact that Congress wonâ€™t actually be putting forth a â€œcleanâ€ CR. Sequestration â€• the automatic spending cuts that were set in 2011 â€• is set to trigger on Jan. 21 absent a deal raising spending caps. When HuffPost asked House Freedom Caucus Chairman Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) whether conservatives would support raising the caps temporarily in a CR, Meadows said heâ€™d favor suspending sequestration for only defense. â€œI donâ€™t know that there is an appetite to increase caps without a better understanding of where our appropriations efforts are headed,â€ he said.Former Freedom Caucus Chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) also told HuffPost on Thursday afternoon that he opposed raising non-defense spending caps in a CR as well. â€œI do not remember the American people electing us to do that,â€ he said.When pressed if he was willing to enter a shutdown over the issue, Jordan reiterated that he was fine raising the spending limits for the military, and if Democrats wouldnâ€™t accept increasing the caps for just defense, it would be them shutting down the government and denying troops a pay raise.Still, barring a mutiny over the caps, Republicans expect theyâ€™ll be able to pass a short-term extension in the House and then get the Senate to back the bill allowing for more time. But thereâ€™s some uncertainty that Senate Democrats would vote for another CR themselves.â€œThere are many reasons that I may not support a CR, including I think itâ€™s time that we take care of our Dreamers,â€ Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-Ore.) told HuffPost on Thursday.When HuffPost asked if he thought Democrats were willing to enter into a shutdown over a dispute on a short-term government funding extension, Merkley said the only responsibility for a shutdown would be with Republicans and the administration. â€œTheyâ€™re in charge,â€ he said.But other Senate Democrats sounded a little more hesitant.Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) said he didnâ€™t know whether Jan. 19th â€• the day funding is set to expire â€• was the line, or if Democrats would extend the deadline. Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) said itâ€™d be â€œsillyâ€ to shut down the government. And Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) said there was no need for a crisis.Itâ€™s unclear, however, how much of that talk downplaying a shutdown is just spin. Democrats say itâ€™d be on Republicans if there was a shutdown. â€œThe only person whoâ€™s been tweeting about a shutdown was the president of the United States,â€ Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) told HuffPost on Thursday. But he also said Democrats couldnâ€™t keep kicking these issues â€œdown the road forever.â€

headline: Latin American Human Rights Court Urges Region To Approve Same-Sex Marriage
short descr: LGBTQ rights advocates celebrated the Jan. 9 decision.
image_caption(s): People celebrate after the Inter-American Court of Human Rights called on Costa Rica and Latin America to recognize equal marriage Jan. 9 in San Jose, Costa Rica.
article: SAN JOSE (Reuters) - A Latin American human rights court said on Tuesday that countries in the region should legalize same-sex unions, endorsing a growing push for marriage equality despite opposition from the Roman Catholic Church.The Inter-American Court of Human Rightsâ€™ decision came in response to a petition submitted two years ago by Costa Rican president Luis Guillermo Solis, who had vowed to increase rights for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people in the majority Catholic country.A number of Latin American countries, including Costa Rica, do not allow same-sex marriage. However, that trend is changing and in recent years same-sex couples have been allowed to marry in Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Uruguay and some parts of Mexico, despite church opposition.The Inter-American Court, based in Costa Ricaâ€™s capital San Jose, said the countries that it oversees should treat same-sex couples â€œwithout discrimination,â€ ensuring that they receive the same family and financial rights as heterosexual couples.It also recommended that these rights be ensured through temporary decrees while governments pursue permanent laws.Costa Ricaâ€™s government celebrated the decision, saying that lawmakers would take steps to adopt the courtâ€™s criteria â€œin its totality.â€â€œThe court ... reminds all states on the continent, including ours, of their obligation and historical debt toward this population,â€ Costa Ricaâ€™s vice president Ana Helena Chacon said at a press conference.

headline: How To Actually Get A Bartender's Attention
short descr: Plus other things they wish you knew.
image_caption(s): We talked to bartenders about how to stand out as a customer.
article: Set the scene: Itâ€™s most likely dark, crowded and noisy, and all you want is a nice, cold drink. Yep, youâ€™re in a bar, and youâ€™re hoping to somehow stand out and get the bartenderâ€™s attention in a sea of thirsty people who want the exact same thing. So how do you do it?We spoke to two bartenders to get some insight into how to get them to notice you and to learn what makes you a good customer (or a bad customer, of course).Most of the advice both bartenders offered can be summed up in two words: Be patient. Gita D. has been a bartender off and on for the past 12 1/2 years, working in Los Angeles, California, as well as Florida. She told HuffPost her biggest pet peeve is when customers clearly see sheâ€™s busy and interrupt her to try and sneak their order in.â€œYouâ€™re running around and sort of talking to yourself â€• â€˜That guy needs a Stella; this guy needs a margarita, an Old-Fashioned and a martini; I need to close the Jones tab,â€™â€ she said. â€œThe biggest pet peeve is if someone interjects into that and throws you off track ... assuming that Iâ€™m not doing anything, even if Iâ€™m clearly standing at the computer.â€Will D., 27, is a full-time bartender in Alabama, and he echoed Gitaâ€™s sentiments. â€œYou arenâ€™t the only person weâ€™re taking care of,â€ he said. â€œYes, you are important to us, but allow us to distribute our time with other guests when talking or even when asking for more things.â€If you want to grab the bartenderâ€™s attention, Will said â€œa simple wave or eye contact will suffice.â€ Gita also suggested eye contact, but she added that staying off your phone and having your cash or card ready to go can help.â€œIf youâ€™re ordering drinks for more than just yourself, have them all prepared. Know what your friends want to drink,â€ she said. â€œIf youâ€™ve got a credit card or youâ€™ve got cash, thatâ€™s a signal that you want to order something. If you have it out, in your hand, ready to go, thatâ€™s my best signal.â€As drinks expert David Wondrich pointed out to The New York Times, though, having your card or cash ready to go is much different than obnoxiously waving it around. As for tipping, both bartenders said 20 percent is the standard. Will told HuffPost some customers will leave $1 per drink for smaller orders, which usually suffices. Gita suggested that before tipping, consider the style of the bar and the complexity of your drink.â€œIf youâ€™re at a fancier place, and it takes four minutes to construct your drink, depending on the quality of the drink and the style of the bartender you may want to throw them an extra buck, or two or three,â€ she said. In an interview with Lifehacker, two bartenders also noted that â€œa decent tip on your first drink says a lot.â€Bartenders are, after all, only human, and they can help you out when youâ€™re in a bind. â€œI canâ€™t tell you how many times Iâ€™ve been yelled or cursed at for making a very minor mistake at work and how much that affects my attitude for the rest of the shift,â€ Will said. â€œBe mindful of how you talk to us!â€And bartenders are often excellent resources for things other than your delicious drinks. â€œIf youâ€™re getting too drunk, ask your bartender to call you a cab. Thatâ€™s what weâ€™re there for,â€ Gita said. â€œIf youâ€™re on a really bad date, let your bartender know â€• sometimes you want to get away from [the date], sometimes youâ€™re scared for your safety.â€She added later, â€œOur job is to help you loosen up ... weâ€™re a part of the party, and itâ€™s a fun gig to have.â€

headline: Trump's New Ambassador Finally Tells Dutch He Was Wrong About Muslim 'No-Go' Zones
short descr: Peter Hoekstra says he "mixed up countries."
image_caption(s): U.S. Ambassador to the Netherlands Peter Hoekstra is questioned during a news conference at the U.S. Embassy in The Hague on Wednesday.
article: President Donald Trumpâ€™s new ambassador to the Netherlands, Peter Hoekstra, has finally admitted that his 2015 comments claiming there were â€œno goâ€ violent zones in the nation because of Muslim immigrants had been baseless.â€œLooking back, I am shocked I said that,â€ Hoekstra said in an interview published Friday in the Dutch newspaper De Telegraaf, according to The Washington Post. â€œIt was a wrong statement. It was wrong.â€Hoekstra claimed at a 2015 anti-terrorism conference that Muslims were causing â€œchaos in the Netherlands,â€ burning cars and politicians and creating â€œno-go zonesâ€ in that country. He told De Telegraaf that he couldnâ€™t recall what his comments were based on. â€œI mixed up countries. I was wrong. I canâ€™t recall how that could happen. I know: I was wrong,â€ he said.Hoekstra has been scorched by the Dutch over the comments, and his De Telegraaf interview appeared to be an attempt to make amends after a tough week.During his first news conference on Wednesday, Dutch journalists refused to let Hoekstra off the hook and peppered the former Republican congressman from Michigan with questions asking if he still believed those widely debunked claims.Hoekstra then doggedly refused to retract his past comments or provide concrete examples to back up his claims, The Washington Post reported. The Dutch journalists responded to his reluctance by piling on their questions. â€œAre politicians being burned in the Netherlands in the past? Is that something you believe? Yes or no?â€ one reporter asked. â€œCould you please take back the remark about burned politicians or name the politician that was burned in the Netherlands?â€ another asked.â€œWhy donâ€™t you answer the question?â€ others chimed in, after Hoekstra attempted to move on.At one point, a frustrated journalist declared, â€œThis is the Netherlands. You have to answer questions.â€Roel Geeraedts, a reporter at the Dutch television station RTL Nieuws, tweeted a video of the tense news conference. â€œThe only one who did get burned today is... Hoekstra himself. By refusing to answer our questions,â€ he wrote.Hoekstra made those claims about Islam during a recorded panel discussion in November 2015. The panel was sponsored by the David Horowitz Freedom Center, a Los Angeles-based organization known for promoting anti-immigrant and anti-Muslim ideologies.â€œThe Islamic movement is now gotten to a point where they have put Europe into chaos,â€ Hoekstra said back then, according to Reuters. â€œChaos in the Netherlands â€• there are cars being burned. There are politicians that are being burned and, yes, there are no-go zones in the Netherlands.â€In fact, there have been no instances of modern Dutch politicians being set on fire, Geeraedts noted in his tweet. The rumor about Muslims in the Netherlands or other parts of Europe creating no-go zones where non-Muslims arenâ€™t welcome is also unsubstantiated, although the myth is often promoted by right-wing groups and individuals seeking to spread misinformation about Islam. Hoekstra has often made erroneous comments about Muslims and their faith. He has speculated that up to 15 percent of all Muslims could be radical extremists, according to CNN. Given that there are roughly 1.8 billion Muslims in the world, that would amount to about 270 million people. headline: A Tiny Tax Hike On People Who Bike To Work Helps Explain The Whole GOP Tax Law
short descr: Nobody seems to know why Republicans singled out cyclists' benefits.
image_caption(s): Eliminating the bike benefit will likely raise a mere $5 million a year in federal revenue.
article: WASHINGTON â€• Tucked inside the sweeping tax package Republicans rushed to enact last month is a tiny provision targeting people who bike to work.Since 2009, businesses have been able to give workers who commute on bikes a tax-free benefit worth $20 a month to cover bike-related expenses. Not anymore: Cyclists will now have to pay taxes on that money.â€œItâ€™s an example of the cats and dogs in this bill,â€ Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Oregon), a staunch advocate of the bike benefit, told HuffPost. â€œEvery week weâ€™re going to find something else that really wasnâ€™t discussed that matters to tens of thousands of people â€• in this case, hundreds of thousands of people potentially.â€Implemented in the wake of the Great Recession, the modest benefit for cyclists was meant to put more parity in the U.S. tax code between those who bike to work and those who drive or take mass transit. Commuters in the latter category have long been eligible for a tax benefit on parking fees and transit fares â€• in the form of a tax break on up to $255 of their monthly pay.Although the bike benefit was pocket change by comparison, cycling advocates say it was an important recognition by the federal government that not everyone drives or takes the subway to work. If your employer provided the benefit, you got reimbursed with tax-free money for necessary cycling expenses â€• like a bike purchase, a tune-up or new equipment such as tires or a helmet.The benefit also served as a modest incentive for people to take a healthy and environmentally friendly mode of travel to their jobs.â€œWhether or not you have free or subsidized parking is a massive determinant in whether you drive to work,â€ explained Colin Browne, a spokesman for the Washington Area Bicyclist Association, an advocacy group for D.C.-area cyclists. â€œThis was a small way to try to balance that out and give folks an alternative.â€The elimination of the bike benefit offers a useful window into how Republicans carried out their very complicated overhaul of the tax code with stunning speed. For starters, many lawmakers, let alone members of the public, didnâ€™t even know the measure was in the bill. No one HuffPost spoke to was able to identify the member or members of Congress who targeted the benefit for elimination. The change first cropped up in a Senate version of the tax package.Spokespeople for the Senate Finance Committee, which drafted the upper chamberâ€™s version of the bill, didnâ€™t respond to a simple question: Why target bikes?Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch (R-Utah), who is retiring from Congress at the end of this year, couldnâ€™t explain it either when HuffPost asked.â€œWeâ€™ve had a lot of different priorities and we didnâ€™t always keep everything we wanted to keep,â€ Hatch said, even though the final version of the bill did keep the bike provision.According to Blumenauer, elimination of the bike benefit will raise an estimated $5 million a year for the federal government â€• barely a rounding error among the $1.5 trillion in tax cuts. Since the provision barely affects revenue, the cycling advocates HuffPost interviewed sensed a political motivation at play. After all, even though people all over the country bike to work, the cyclists are more likely to live in or near big cities than in rural areas.Like the highly controversial elimination of the state and local tax deduction, the death of the bike benefit may have been a way to stick it to liberals who live on the coasts, shop at Whole Foods and vote for Democrats. But nobody seems to know for sure.â€œIt could certainly be that. Or it could just be one [senator] who had a bad experience with a cyclist,â€ said Ken McLeod, policy director at the League of American Bicyclists, a national advocacy group. â€œItâ€™s a relatively innocuous benefit that doesnâ€™t cost the federal government pretty much anything. It seems like it must be a personal or cultural thing rather than actual public policy.â€The bike policy is one of several changes to employee fringe benefits in the new tax law, which offsets the revenue lost in corporate and individual tax cuts with an assortment of revenue increases. Tens of billions of dollars will be raised by disallowing employers from deducting the full value of worker compensation that takes the form of commuter benefits, entertainment, meals and employee achievement awards.The law still allows employers to deduct bike-specific compensation on their corporate returns, but doesnâ€™t let them provide that monthly $20 tax-free to employees. Workers who drive or take mass transit, however, can still get tax-free reimbursements.Itâ€™s unclear if employers will continue to provide the bike benefit if itâ€™s less attractive to workers. The League of American Bicyclists encouraged bike commuters to take full advantage of their benefits before the end of last year.Along with Blumenauer, Rep. Vern Buchanan (R-Fla.) is co-chair of the congressional bike caucus. Heâ€™s also a member of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, yet even he seemed blindsided by the shift in bike tax policy.â€œWe gotta change that,â€ Buchanan said. â€œI just havenâ€™t focused on that but now that you brought it up, I will.â€Arthur Delaney co-hosts the HuffPost Politics podcast:

headline: Bernie Sanders Says Trump Budget Exposes President As Fake Populist
short descr: "This is a budget for the billionaire class, for Wall Street, for corporate CEOs and for the wealthiest people in this country."
image_caption(s): Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) on Tuesday accused President Donald Trump of failing to live up to his campaign promises.
article: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) savaged President Donald Trumpâ€™s budget proposal on Tuesday, accusing the president of turning his back on campaign pledges to stand up for struggling Americans.Sanders, who caucuses with Democrats, rattled off the budgetâ€™s numerous cuts to safety net and social insurance programs, as well as tax cuts for wealthy Americans and corporations, while speaking at a press conference held by Democratic leaders in Congress.Trumpâ€™s fiscal priorities prove he was never a serious advocate for the working and middle classes, the senator added.â€œWhen Donald Trump campaigned for president, he told the American people he would be a different type of Republican, that he would take on the political and economics establishment, that he would stand up for working people, that he understood the pain that families all across this country were experiencing,â€ said Sanders, the ranking member of the Senate Budget Committee.â€œWell, sadly this budget exposes all of that verbiage for what it really was: just cheap and dishonest campaign rhetoric that was meant to get votes â€• nothing more than that,â€ he added. â€œAt a time when the rich are already getting richer, while the middle class continues to shrink, this is a budget for the billionaire class, for Wall Street, for corporate CEOs and for the wealthiest people in this country.â€Trumpâ€™s budget makes cuts to disability insurance under Social Security, even though he promised not to touch the program, noted Rep. John Yarmuth (D-Ky.), the ranking member of the House Budget Committee. Yarmuth appeared at the press conference alongside Sanders, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.).â€œThe presidentâ€™s budget was a betrayal, a line-by-line tally of broken promises he made to the American people,â€ Yarmuth said.Itâ€™s ultimately up to Congress to decide how much to spend on everything from the military to programs like Meals on Wheels. Still, Trumpâ€™s budget is a useful window into the White Houseâ€™s worldview â€• which is why Democrats have wasted no time pouncing on it.The rhetoric of Sanders, who launched an unexpectedly competitive bid for the Democratic presidential nomination with a campaign platform of economic populism, has sometimes been compared to that of Trump, who found success by highlighting his anti-establishment tendencies (albeit with a racial demagoguery that was anathema to Sanders).Sanders has a made a point of trying to hold Trump to his promises to fight for working people â€• even insisting that it could be grounds for bipartisan cooperation.The Vermont senator said in a statement the day after the election that he and other progressives would be willing to work with the president â€œto the degree that [he] is serious about pursuing policies that improve the lives of working families in this country.â€For a lawmaker like Sanders, this was a win-win proposition. In the unlikely event that Trump governed progressively, Sanders could claim a policy victory. And the senator had ammunition to attack the president if he did not.So far, Sanders hasnâ€™t found much to like in Trumpâ€™s agenda â€• even when it comes to issues like trade policy, on which Sanders and Trump both defy the bipartisan, pro-business consensus in favor of trade agreements. The support of Democratic senators ensured the confirmation of United States Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, a trade hawk who enjoys a good reputation among progressive experts. But Sanders was one of 11 members of the Democratic caucus to vote against confirming Lighthizer, complaining that the nominee was insufficiently committed to reforming a status quo on trade that privileges corporate profits over human need.

headline: Donald Trump's Budget Makes A Really Basic Numbers Error
short descr: Whoops!
image_caption(s): Mick Mulvaney, director of the White House's Office of Management and Budget, tried to defend an arithmetic error identified by center-left economist Lawrence Summers.
article: The White House made a basic mathematical error when trying to prove that massive tax cuts would pay for themselves and then some, according to a leading economist who advised former President Barack Obama. In a column in The Washington Post on Tuesday, Lawrence Summers, who directed Obamaâ€™s national economic council from 2009 to 2010, took the current White House to task for double-counting $2 trillion in revenue it predicts its tax cuts will generate.President Donald Trumpâ€™s budget proposal assumes that the tax cuts it would enact for wealthy individuals and corporations, as well as its reductions in regulations, will create consistent 3 percent economic growth â€• enough to generate $2 trillion a year in additional revenue.That projection in itself is dubious; tax cuts rarely, if ever, spur enough growth to replenish the revenue they cost the Treasury. But it is nonetheless a prediction consistent with the supply-side economics that Republicans have been peddling for decades.Where Trumpâ€™s budget team really got it wrong is in claiming that the tax cuts would both pay for themselves and close the existing budget deficit.â€œThis is an elementary double count,â€ Summers writes. â€œYou canâ€™t use the growth benefits of tax cuts once to justify an optimistic baseline and then again to claim that the tax cuts do not cost revenue. At least you cannot do so in a world of logic.â€New York magazineâ€™s Jonathan Chait shoots down one plausible explanation for the error.â€œTrump could be assuming that his tax cuts will not only pay for themselves but generate $2 trillion in higher revenue. But Trump has not claimed his tax cuts will recoup more than 100 percent of their lost revenue, so itâ€™s simply an embarrassing mistake,â€ he writes.Mick Mulvaney, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, defended the apparent mistake in his press conference on Tuesday.He claimed that any overly rosy assumptions about tax cut-generated revenue are more than offset by conservative estimates elsewhere. For instance, the administration did not account for the ways in which simplifying the tax code could allow the government to collect taxes that normally go unpaid, because people either do not understand their taxes or are too frustrated by their complexity to pay them, according to Mulvaney.â€œIf you can really fill out your ... tax returns on a single piece of paper, youâ€™re much more likely to actually do it. Itâ€™s also easier for us to see if youâ€™re paying the right amount,â€ he said.Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin was more forthright about the arithmetic error in an interview with CNBCâ€™s John Harwood on Tuesday, emphasizing that the budget is merely a â€œpreliminary document.â€ During a House Budget Committee hearing on Capitol Hill on Wednesday, Mulvaney flatly denied that Trumpâ€™s budget double-counts $2 trillion in revenue, despite evidence otherwise.â€œThe dynamic benefit is only counted one time and thatâ€™s toward the 3 percent economic growth. And Iâ€™m happy to explain that to you further in writing if you like,â€ he told Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz (D-Fla.).â€œYou can explain whatever youâ€™d like, you are counting revenue twice,â€ Wasserman Schultz shot back. â€œAnd saying that the budget is balanced, and anyone running their household budget would be in serious trouble down the road â€• that is where you are taking us.â€This article has been updated with additional comment from Mulvaney.

headline: Trump's Policies May Cost The U.S. $1.3 Billion, And That's Just In Travel
short descr: Experts say his moves could cost lots of jobs.
image_caption(s): International tourism makes about $250 billion annually for the U.S., according to the Department of Commerce.
article: The U.S. will likely miss out on more than $1.3 billion in travel-related expenditures this year, in part due to the Trump administrationâ€™s policies, one international business travel group predicts.A loss in that range could mean thousands of lost jobs, and some other analysts project the overall monetary losses will be much higher.Political events like Brexit, President Donald Trumpâ€™s executive order â€œtravel bans,â€ new laptop bans in the U.S. and U.K. and rumors of an expanded U.S. laptop ban have created â€œuncertaintyâ€ thatâ€™s keeping some international travelers from visiting the U.S., according to a new report from the Global Business Travel Association, which represents corporate travel managers and professionals. The organizationâ€™s researchers analyzed airfare bookings, figures like GDP and oil prices and a Department of Commerce survey to come up with an â€œuncertainty forecastâ€ of $1.3 billion in losses in hotel, food, rental car and shopping spending related to travelers. The figure also includes $175 million in lost business travel-related wages for Americans during 2017.â€œThis devastating economic impact could take years to recover from,â€ wrote GBTAâ€™s executive director & COO Mike McCormick. Staff at Oxford Economics said that projection is far too low. The global advisory firm is predicting an even bigger drop in travel to the U.S. this year, one that would result in a total loss of over $2.4 billion. The cause, they say, is Trumpâ€™s harmful rhetoric affecting perceptions abroad.â€œâ€™America firstâ€™ rhetoric, which was pronounced during the campaign and Trumpâ€™s inauguration speech, is finding consistent expression in policy,â€ said Adam Sacks, president of Oxford Economicsâ€™s tourism department. â€œInternational markets are receiving a message that America is no longer a welcoming destination.â€The federal government estimates the value of international travel and tourism to the U.S. at about $250 billion annually, with three percent growth projected every year, said Patrick Surry, chief data scientist at travel site Hopper. The GBTAâ€™s forecasted $1.3 billion loss represents about a .5 percent shift. But thatâ€™s too conservative in Surryâ€™s eyes: Hopperâ€™s recent research shows a more pronounced drop in U.S. travel interest since Trump took office. Chinese travelers, for example, have searched for flights to the U.S. 40 percent less than average since Trump took office.The Middle East represents a particularly big hit, according to both the GBTA and Oxford Economics.â€œWeâ€™re seeing a 30 percent decline in travel to the U.S. from the Middle East at the moment,â€ Sacks said. â€œThis means that the U.S. economy stands to lose about $1 billion from Middle East travelers alone [this year].â€ Emirates Airlines recently cut service to the U.S. after demand weakened in the wake of Trumpâ€™s travel bans and the Department of Homeland Security laptop ban, which was enacted in late March. And in a GBTA poll conducted after Trumpâ€™s initial travel ban, about half of European business executives said they would plan their travel elsewhere.Amid Trumpâ€™s review of certain work visas and rumors of an expanded laptop ban, â€œglobal travel markets will take further cues that the U.S. is not as welcoming as it once was,â€ Sack said.Ouch.

headline: For A Brighter Future In The Middle East, Reform Education Before It Is Too Late!
authors: Helen Al Uzaizi, ContributorBizWorld UAE CEO
short descr: In the recently published Arab Youth Survey (Arab Youth Survey) there was one alarming figure that caught my attention: 66
image_caption(s): Young children in Jordan at the Abdul Hameed Shoman Foundation, learning business terminology.
article: In the recently published Arab Youth Survey (Arab Youth Survey) there was one alarming figure that caught my attention: 66 percent of youth in the Levant and North Africa regions are not satisfied with the way the education system is preparing them for future jobs. That is an overwhelming number, especially when average youth unemployment rates are already between 25-30 percent. This does not bode well for the economic and social outlook of the Arab world, especially when you consider future factors such as automation and an increasingly competitive global economy.While the GCC fares better, 80 percent satisfaction rates with the education system, the entire MENA region averages at a 49 percent dissatisfaction rate. Education, from primary school and onwards, is vital to developing a nationâ€™s workforce, not just in capacity and knowledge building, but shaping personalities of industrious and innovative citizens.However, if all these smart and capable youth have limited or no job opportunities, an exodus of human capital can leave a nation in a more precarious situation. That is why governments across the region have prioritized entrepreneurship as the best way to create job opportunities for their growing populations. Capable entrepreneurs donâ€™t just grow on trees though; they need to be nurtured at an early age to truly bridge the unemployment gap â€” this is why:The regionâ€™s education system needs to play a greater role in educating children about entrepreneurship as a viable career path and preparing them with the right skills to succeed as business leaders and innovators. The foundations are there for us to build on; all people, regardless of social or economic backgrounds are born with an entrepreneurial spirit, the key is to nurture and develop the traits and skills that define a successful entrepreneur. As we develop these skills, future entrepreneurs will be better prepared for the challenges of launching a business and create a greater impact in the future. Whatâ€™s important to emphasize is that these skills need to be developed as early as seven or eight years old to truly shape that entrepreneurial mindset. In parallel to developing these skills, it is crucial to supplement this knowledge with financial literacy to further equip future generations to better manage their money and navigate a complex financial system. To start, both public and private schools can implement curriculums, such as the BizWorld programs, that educate children with basic business vocabulary, finance, the manufacturing process, and other critical business functions to give children a practical introduction into the entrepreneurship world. Teaching these practical business skills, financial literacy, and with technology-focused classes we can better prepare students for future jobs. This is only half the story though, future entrepreneurs and leaders will need to have developed skills that go beyond business basics and financial literacy. The education system needs to develop childrenâ€™s critical thinking skills and move away from the memorize-repeat cycle. The system also needs to develop childrenâ€™s creativity and ingenuity in addition to so many other personality and behavioral traits that fuel entrepreneurs to thrive despite of the challenges they will surely face. If we are to reform the education system so it no longer fails our youth, but instead acts as a springboard for them to lead successful and fulfilling lives, we need to teach with the future in mind and to the opportunities that will be available. As much as itâ€™s said that our children are our future, then we need to start investing in them and in their education, so they not only live up to their own potential, but make our region more competitive globally and create great examples of Arab progress and innovation. Helen Al Uzaizi is the CEO of BizWorld UAE and founder of the entrepreneurship education platform for the MENA region, Future Entrepreneurs. With a 15+ year career in the corporate and start-up worlds, Helen directed her passion to the entrepreneurship education field, working to instill the entrepreneurial mindset in the next generation of leaders.
